column3: *Go doesn't affect words that begin with a consonant, but if the name begins with a vowel, h is placed before it.
Go dtí is used before nouns that are preceded by the article:

column2: Tá mé ag dul go dtí an t-ospidéal.
column3: I am going to the hospital.
The word chuig is used instead of go or go dtí when you're talking about going to an event or to see a person. We'll deal with chuig in more detail in Aonad 11.

column2: Tá mé ag dul go Gaillimh...

column3: The word uair is irregular when preceded by numbers:
This word occurs quite frequently in everyday speech, so it is well worth learning the different forms.

We've already come across tá many times during this course. When you're referring to something that recurs, either frequently or infrequently, you need to use the present habitual form:
(I am always tired in the evening.)

column3: (I am always late on Monday morning.)

column2: Here are the ordinal numbers from the first to tenth:
DESCRIBING THE CONTENTS OF A HOUSE
As we saw in earlier units, i or in is the Irish for 'in':
Tá mé i mo chónaí i mBaile Átha Cliath.
However, 'in the' is one word in Irish: sa(n).
Sa adds a séimhiú to words beginning with a consonant (except d, n, t, l, and s):
And san is used before words beginning with a vowel:
